title: 105_hr4046
content: Restrictions on transfers or discharges of nursing facility residents in case of voluntary withdrawal from Medicaid program. In case of voluntary withdrawal from Medicaid program, nursing facility residents have continuing rights. Residents of a nursing facility have the right to continue receiving services even if the facility voluntarily withdraws from a State plan under this title. Withdrawal cannot be used as a reason to transfer or discharge residents who were residing in the facility before the withdrawal. Residents of a nursing facility have the right to continue receiving services even if the facility withdraws from a State plan. The provisions of this section apply to residents until their discharge, and new residents are also covered by the facility's obligations. Residents of a nursing facility have the right to receive services even if the facility withdraws from a State plan. New residents must be informed orally and in writing about their rights upon admission. Residents of a nursing facility must receive information from each individual upon admission, including an acknowledgment of receipt in writing. This does not affect any participation requirements. Residents of a nursing facility must receive information from each individual upon admission, including an acknowledgment of receipt in writing. This does not affect any participation requirements. The information for new residents includes details about the facility. The facility must provide information to new residents, including details about non-participation in the program and the ability to transfer or discharge residents unable to pay charges. The facility has the authority to transfer or discharge residents who are unable to pay charges, even if they become eligible for medical assistance. Continuation of payments and oversight authority for residents under this title, despite facility withdrawal from participation in the State plan. After a facility voluntarily withdraws from the State plan, they can still receive payments for nursing facility services, maintain compliance with requirements, and continue to apply for oversight under this title. After voluntarily withdrawing from the State plan, a facility can still receive payments for nursing facility services while maintaining compliance with all applicable requirements and continuing to apply for oversight under this title. The provisions of this subparagraph apply to a significant voluntary reduction in participation under a State plan for a resident entitled to medical assistance under this title. The provisions apply to a significant voluntary reduction in participation under a State plan for a resident entitled to medical assistance with nursing facility services. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to voluntary withdrawals from participation in nursing facility services for residents entitled to medical assistance. The provision does not apply to new residents who begin residence in a facility after the effective date of the withdrawal. The amendment applies to voluntary withdrawals from nursing facility services for residents entitled to medical assistance. A report on the impact of the implementation must be submitted to Congress within 5 years of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The report will analyze the impact of changes in Medicaid reimbursement rates on nursing facilities and make recommendations for legislative changes.
